key_points: One person reportedly died during the operation to free the Ever Given ship in the Suez Canal in March.
The Suez Canal Authority (SCA) reported the death among their 'most prominent losses' due to the incident.
The specifics of the death, including the identity and exact cause, remain unclear.
The Suez Canal Authority mentioned the sinking of a rescue boat and the redirection of 48 ships as additional losses.
The death occurred amidst the efforts to salvage the Ever Given, which ran aground in April and was stuck for six days.
There are no records of a tugboat or marine unit sinking, which raises questions about the details provided.
The SCA demands $600 million in compensation from Shoei Kisen Kaisha, the Japanese owner of Ever Given, for the incident.
The ship's insurer considers the $600 million compensation demand too high, while the initial demand was $916 million.
Ever Given was impounded in the Great Bitter Lake, around 30 miles from where it got stuck.
The blockage of the Ever Given significantly disrupted global trade for six days.
